item.title: Tile Concept Explained
item.description: What is a Tile? A common technique to display maps on a computer is to divide the map into a grid (XY-plane) of rectangles. Each rectangle in this grid is called a map tile and together the grid becomes a tile grid. This enables a map application to only load visible tiles instead of the entire map. How the grid is constructed is determined by the map creator. To refer to a specific tile it is common to either use the XY-planes respective X and Y coordinate or to have a tile-id that combines the plane coordinate into a single number.

item.title: Authentication
item.description: Authentication Overview There are two different ways to authenticate against the API endpoints. The first way is a normal login process. This process is to be used if you have been given a username and password. The second way is to use an API Access-Token. This token is generated by NIRA and not the end user, so unless you have been given one, use the login authentication process. Login Authentication Process By calling the login endpoint with your username and password you will be given an AUTH_SESSION cookie in return.

item.title: Data Bundles
item.description: Data Bundles Below you will find a description about the different data bundles which are available in the NIRA API. The names of these different data bundles are referred to as bundle_name in the API endpoint documentation. Note that you might not have permission to fetch data from all data bundles listed here. road-segment-aggregation-2 The road-segment-aggregation-2 bundle contains layers with friction information. For this bundle, the available timestamp is in 10 minute increments and the data is produced with a delay of around 10 minutes.

item.title: Google Protocol Buffer Explained
item.description: Google Protocol Buffer (Proto) You can read what Protocol Buffers (Proto, Protobuf) are at Google’s documentation. NIRA uses them as the return response from the HERE-tile APIs (it is also used for Mapbox Vector tile) to package the data in a compact format. The output from these APIs will be in binary format which you will need a declaration of the .proto format used to decode. NIRA supplies different .

item.title: Test the API
item.description: Overview NIRA provides an OpenAPI 3.0 specification file that can be used with your favorite testing program. The tool we will use is Postman. Additionally, you will need a tool for decoding the protobuf response files. We will use Protoc. Test with Postman Download API definition here . Download Postman. Import the API definition into Postman. During import click on “Show advanced settings” and change the following: “Naming requests” to URL.

item.title: Code Examples
item.description: Code Examples Below are some code examples to do specific operations related to the API. Computing Tile Id Scala val LonRange = 360 val LatRange = 180 def getTileId(lat: Double, lon: Double, zoomLevel: Int): Long = { // find x,y tile indexes val x: Int = scala.math .floor((lon + LonRange / 2) / getDegreesPerTile(zoomLevel)) .toInt val y: Int = scala.math .floor((lat + LatRange / 2) / getDegreesPerTile(zoomLevel)) .toInt interleaveAndGetTileId(zoomLevel, x, y) } private def getDegreesPerTile(zoomLevel: Int): Double = LonRange / scala.
